header_summary:
AdamISZ, also known as waxwing, explores the potential of adaptor signatures to expand beyond their current limitations in cryptographic protocols, particularly in the realm of on-chain verification and Zero-Knowledge Proofs (ZKP). His [blog post](https://reyify.com/blog/adaptors-generalised/) delves into a two-party protocol that could allow verification of Discrete Logarithm Equality (DLEQ) through the publication of a BIP340 signature, highlighting both theoretical and practical applications of this concept. 

MishaKomarov introduces Bitcoin PIPEs, a novel approach to implementing covenants in Bitcoin that bypasses the need for soft forks. This method enhances Bitcoin's scripting capabilities, enabling advanced spending conditions, the creation of native tokens, and the verification of Zero-Knowledge Proofs without altering the core protocol, as detailed in the [discussion](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/bitcoin-pipes-introducting-covenants-without-soft-forks/1183). Bitcoin PIPEs represent a significant step towards more flexible and secure transactions within the Bitcoin network, leveraging Polynomial Inner Product Encryption to emulate missing opcodes and facilitate complex transaction conditions.

AJ Towns highlights the integration of Plotly.js within a Discourse theme component, offering advanced data visualization options directly in forums. This development allows for interactive graphs and complex visualizations, such as geographical trajectories, through simple text markup, potentially revolutionizing data representation in online discussions. The component's versatility and ease of use are showcased in an example comparing old and new mempool configurations, with further details and possibilities explored in Plotly's extensive [documentation](https://plotly.com/javascript/).

recent_posts.title: Adaptor generalisation
recent_posts.summary:
- AdamISZ/waxwing's blog post explores expanding adaptor signatures in cryptography.
- It discusses a protocol for verifying a DLEQ statement between two parties.
- The post also considers integrating generalized sigma protocols with adaptor signatures.

recent_posts.title: Bitcoin PIPEs: Introducting Covenants without Soft Forks
recent_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin PIPEs facilitate complex Bitcoin transactions without needing a soft fork.
- They enable advanced spending rules and new use cases like Zero-Knowledge Proofs.
- This innovation preserves Bitcoin's security while expanding its functionality significantly.

recent_posts.title: Support for graphing data
recent_posts.summary:
- Plotly.js integration in a Discourse theme enhances data visualization in forums.
- Users can interact with graphs, including zoom and pan features, for detailed analysis.
- Plotly supports complex visualizations, like world maps, and is customizable.

active_posts.title: Bitcoin Core 28.0 Released
active_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin Core version 28.0 is now available, featuring new functionalities and several optimizations.
- It introduces Testnet4/BIP94 support, enhanced P2P and Tor connection handling, and wallet updates.
- Users are advised to replace old files with the new version for an upgrade.

active_posts.title: Pure Swift Bitcoin Protocol implementation (largely experimental)
active_posts.summary:
- Swift Bitcoin project delves into Bitcoin's mechanics, focusing on several key functionalities.
- It features Swift APIs for crypto transactions and aims for data race safety with SwiftNIO.
- Open for contributions, the project explores evolving from an educational tool to broader use.

active_posts.title: Public disclosure of three vulnerabilities affecting Bitcoin Core <v25.0
active_posts.summary:
- Significant security vulnerabilities were identified in Bitcoin Core versions before 25.0.
- A new vulnerability disclosure policy aims to improve transparency and security within Bitcoin Core.
- Future announcements will disclose vulnerabilities in versions before 26.0, showing ongoing commitment to security.

active_posts.title: SuperScalar: Laddered Timeout-Tree-Structured Decker-Wattenhofer Factories
active_posts.summary:
- The SuperScalar mechanism enhances Bitcoin Lightning Network liquidity without blockchain changes.
- It integrates Decker-Wattenhofer mechanisms, timeout trees, and laddering strategies for scalability and security.
- Practical deployment focuses on user onlineness, efficient liquidity allocation, and balancing update efficiency with exit costs.

active_posts.title: Unspendable keys in descriptors
active_posts.summary:
- Miniscript and taproot integration in Bitcoin Core enhances wallet development possibilities.
- Challenges include creating unique, indistinguishable unspendable keys while minimizing entropy.
- Despite various methods, a consensus on the best approach for unspendable keys remains elusive.

active_posts.title: Non-disclosure of a consensus bug in btcd
active_posts.summary:
- In March 2024, a consensus bug in btcd was fixed in version 0.24.2.
- The authors value transparency but delayed full details citing requests and caution.
- They urge upgrading immediately to protect against vulnerabilities in a small network fraction.

today_in_history_posts.title: Thoughts on scaling and consensus changes (2023)
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin scalability targets 50,000 off-chain "bitcoin banks" for a billion weekly users.
- Proposed solutions include federated sidechains and Coinpools without trusted third parties.
- Effective scaling may blend Bitcoin's integrity with innovations like `OP_VAULT` for security.
